title: Short-term rentals: A smart investment choice
text:
His property answered a strong demand for affordable self-catering holiday accommodation in a popular tourist destination.

The character-filled 1930s home, with three roomy bedrooms, two lounge rooms and a cubby-house and goldfish pond in its pretty garden, has strong appeal for families, who form the majority of Berggren’s client base.

“My visitors are mainly holidaymakers,” he says. “And many are families who wouldn’t stay in a hotel here, if that was their only option.”

At an average of $155 per night, and with no charge for children 13 and under, Berggren’s property brings a Tasmanian holiday within budget for many.

For larger families, he says, the costs of staying in a hotel can be a major obstacle and can even push the price of a holiday beyond reach.

“One family who stayed here had four boys. For them, it made all the difference between making a trip and not making a trip.”

Berggren has invested in the guest experience with thoughtful touches to delight his younger visitors, such as a welcome gift for the littlest ones.

“I have repeat visitors, and I’m very happy with the comments I get on the feedback sheet. It gives me a lovely feeling.”

The property’s financials tell a similarly happy story. To purchase the home, Berggren took out an interest-only mortgage. The property required little upfront capital expenditure; it was in good shape, with modern fittings alongside its original character features, and no major renovations required to prepare it for the short-term rental market.

The property’s rental income is almost three times the interest-only repayments on Berggren’s mortgage loan. “If I pay off the mortgage loan, it starts to look like a really good return, clearing about seven per cent,” he says.

“When you look at the outgoings and the income, right now, it’s a great return on the amount of money I’ve got invested.”

The property’s rental income has been consistent, too, with an occupancy rate of around 60 per cent – above average for the area.

“Before deciding to go into the market, I had monitored a number of properties around Launceston to see what their occupation rate was. My recollection is that 50 per cent was common,” says Berggren.

“There’s possible appreciation, too. The property is close to the university, which has expanded, and the area is attractive, with lots of older homes which give it plenty of charm.”

The benefits of short-term rental go beyond the balance sheet, says Berggren, who’s a retired executive.

“If you’re no longer working full-time, it can keep your skills – especially communication skills – up to date,” he says. “It keeps you active and alert, too, if you choose to do some of the maintenance yourself.”

At the same time, he enjoys the freedom of the low-maintenance Stayz listing platform, which can be managed almost entirely remotely. “I have installed a key safe so I don't have to meet visitors in person, and that frees me up to do everything from home, apart from the cleaning between tenants, which I’ve now outsourced.”

Three years in, and with increasing occupancy rates for the property, Berggren is more than satisfied with his decision to list the property as a short-term holiday rental.

“I certainly have no regrets about it. I’m very happy with how it’s going,” he says.

description: When Sven Berggren bought his three-bedroom investment property in Launceston, Tasmania, three years ago he didn’t initially envisage renting it out to short-term guests.
